supporting_quotes.quote: If there is sufficient sea room, alteration of course alone may be the most effective action to avoid a close-quarters situation provided that it is made in good time, is substantial and does not result in another close-quarters situation.

question: When must a vessel required not to impede passage take early action?
truth_answer: When required by the circumstances to allow sufficient sea room for safe passage of the other vessel.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel which, by any of these Rules, is required not to impede the passage or safe passage of another vessel shall, when required by the circumstances of the case, take early action to allow sufficient sea room for the safe passage of the other vessel.

question: Is a vessel whose passage is not to be impeded relieved from the Rules when approaching?
truth_answer: No, she remains fully obliged to comply with the Rules when approaching so as to involve risk of collision.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel the passage of which is not to be impeded remains fully obliged to comply with the rules of this part when the two vessels are approaching one another so as to involve risk of collision.

question: On which side should a vessel keep in a narrow channel?
truth_answer: As near to the outer limit on her starboard side as is safe and practicable.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel proceeding along the course of a narrow channel or fairway shall keep as near to the outer limit of the channel or fairway which lies on her starboard side as is safe and practicable.

question: Can a sailing vessel impede a large vessel in a narrow channel?
truth_answer: No, a sailing vessel shall not impede passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within the channel.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel of less than 20 metres in length or a sailing vessel shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel

question: Should vessels anchor in narrow channels?
truth_answer: No, any vessel shall, if circumstances admit, avoid anchoring in a narrow channel.

supporting_quotes.quote: Any vessel shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid anchoring in a narrow channel.

question: What signal must be sounded when nearing a blind bend?
truth_answer: One prolonged blast.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel nearing a bend or an area of a channel or fairway where other vessels may be obscured by an intervening obstruction shall sound one prolonged blast.

question: Can the overtaken vessel refuse to permit overtaking in a narrow channel?
truth_answer: Yes, if in doubt she may sound at least five short and rapid blasts rather than the agreement signal.

supporting_quotes.quote: The vessel to be overtaken shall, if in agreement, sound the appropriate signal prescribed in Rule 34(c)(ii) and take steps to permit safe passing. If in doubt she may sound the signals prescribed in Rule 34(d).

question: At what angle should vessels cross traffic lanes?
truth_answer: On a heading as nearly as practicable at right angles to the general direction of traffic flow.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel shall so far as practicable avoid crossing traffic lanes, but if obliged to do so shall cross on a heading as nearly as practicable at right angles to the general direction of traffic flow.

question: Should vessels avoid anchoring in traffic separation schemes?
truth_answer: Yes, so far as practicable avoid anchoring in a scheme or near its terminations.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel shall so far as practicable avoid anchoring in a traffic separation scheme or in areas near its terminations.

question: Can fishing vessels impede traffic lanes?
truth_answer: No, a vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede passage of any vessel following a traffic lane.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of any vessel following a traffic lane.

question: Can sailing vessels under 20 metres use the inshore traffic zone?
truth_answer: Yes, sailing vessels may use the inshore traffic zone.

supporting_quotes.quote: vessels of less than 20 meters in length, sailing vessels and vessels engaged in fishing may use the inshore traffic zone.

question: Are vessels laying submarine cables exempt from Rule 10 in a TSS?
truth_answer: Yes, to the extent necessary to carry out the operation.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when engaged in an operation for the laying, servicing or picking up of a submarine cable, within a traffic separation scheme, is exempted from complying with this Rule to the extent necessary to carry out the operation.

question: Should vessels not using a TSS stay clear of it?
truth_answer: Yes, avoid it by as wide a margin as is practicable.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel not using a traffic separation scheme shall avoid it by as wide a margin as is practicable.

question: When may a vessel use the inshore traffic zone?
truth_answer: When en route to/from a port, installation, pilot station within the zone, or to avoid immediate danger.

supporting_quotes.quote: a vessel may use an inshore traffic zone when en route to or from a port, offshore installation or structure, pilot station or any other place situated within the inshore traffic zone, or to avoid immediate danger.

question: Which vessel keeps clear when two sailing vessels have wind on different sides?
truth_answer: The vessel with wind on the port side keeps out of the way.

supporting_quotes.quote: when each has the wind on a different side, the vessel which has the wind on the port side shall keep out of the way of the other

question: Which vessel keeps clear when both sailing vessels have wind on the same side?
truth_answer: The vessel to windward keeps out of the way of the vessel to leeward.

supporting_quotes.quote: when both have the wind on the same side, the vessel which is to windward shall keep out of the way of the vessel which is to leeward

question: How is windward side determined for square-rigged vessels?
truth_answer: The side opposite to that on which the largest fore-and-aft sail is carried.

supporting_quotes.quote: For the purposes of this Rule the windward side shall be deemed to be the side opposite to that on which the mainsail is carried or, in the case of a square-rigged vessel, the side opposite to that on which the largest fore-and-aft sail is carried.

question: If uncertain whether overtaking, what should a vessel assume?
truth_answer: Assume that she is overtaking and act accordingly.

supporting_quotes.quote: When a vessel is in any doubt as to whether she is overtaking another, she shall assume that this is the case and act accordingly.

question: Does Rule 13 override other rules in Part B?
truth_answer: Yes, notwithstanding anything in Rules of Part B Sections I and II, any overtaking vessel keeps out of the way.

supporting_quotes.quote: Notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of Part B, Sections I and II any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken.

question: What action do both vessels take in a head-on situation?
truth_answer: Each shall alter course to starboard to pass port to port.

supporting_quotes.quote: When two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal or nearly reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision each shall alter her course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other.

question: How is a head-on situation determined at night?
truth_answer: When she could see the masthead lights of the other in a line or nearly in a line and/or both sidelights.

supporting_quotes.quote: Such a situation shall be deemed to exist when a vessel sees the other ahead or nearly ahead and by night she could see the masthead lights of the other in a line or nearly in a line and/or both sidelights

question: If in doubt whether a head-on situation exists, what should be assumed?
truth_answer: Assume it does exist and act accordingly.

supporting_quotes.quote: When a vessel is in any doubt as to whether such a situation exists she shall assume that it does exist and act accordingly.

question: Should the give-way vessel cross ahead in a crossing situation?
truth_answer: No, if circumstances admit, she shall avoid crossing ahead of the other vessel.

supporting_quotes.quote: the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way and shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of the other vessel.

question: What type of action must the give-way vessel take?
truth_answer: Early and substantial action to keep well clear.

supporting_quotes.quote: Every vessel which is directed to keep out of the way of another vessel shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action to keep well clear.

question: When may the stand-on vessel take action alone?
truth_answer: As soon as it becomes apparent the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action.

supporting_quotes.quote: The latter vessel may however take action to avoid collision by her manoeuvre alone, as soon as it becomes apparent to her that the vessel required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action

question: What course alteration should a stand-on power-driven vessel avoid in a crossing situation?
truth_answer: If circumstances admit, not alter course to port for a vessel on her own port side.

supporting_quotes.quote: A power-driven vessel which takes action in a crossing situation in accordance with sub-paragraph (a)(ii) of this Rule to avoid collision with another power-driven vessel shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, not alter course to port for a vessel on her own port side.

question: What vessels must a power-driven vessel keep clear of?
truth_answer: Vessels not under command, restricted in ability to manoeuvre, engaged in fishing, and sailing vessels.

supporting_quotes.quote: A power-driven vessel underway shall keep out of the way of: a vessel not under command; a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre; a vessel engaged in fishing; a sailing vessel.

question: What vessels must a fishing vessel keep clear of?
truth_answer: Vessels not under command and vessels restricted in ability to manoeuvre.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel engaged in fishing when underway shall, so far as possible, keep out of the way of: a vessel not under command; a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre.

question: Must seaplanes generally keep clear of vessels?
truth_answer: Yes, in general keep well clear of all vessels and avoid impeding their navigation.

supporting_quotes.quote: A seaplane on the water shall, in general, keep well clear of all vessels and avoid impeding their navigation.

question: Must a seaplane comply with Part B when risk of collision exists?
truth_answer: Yes, she shall comply with the Rules of Part B when risk of collision exists.

supporting_quotes.quote: In circumstances, however, where risk of collision exists, she shall comply with the Rules of this Part.

question: How must a WIG craft operate when on the water surface?
truth_answer: Comply with the Rules of Part B as a power-driven vessel.

supporting_quotes.quote: a WIG craft operating on the water surface shall comply with the Rules of this Part as a power-driven vessel.

question: What must a WIG craft do when taking off or landing?
truth_answer: Keep well clear of all other vessels and avoid impeding their navigation.

supporting_quotes.quote: A WIG craft shall, when taking off, landing and in flight near the surface, keep well clear of all other vessels and avoid impeding their navigation

question: What additional light does a WIG craft show when in flight near the surface?
truth_answer: A high intensity all-round flashing red light.

supporting_quotes.quote: A WIG craft only when taking off, landing and in flight near the surface shall, in addition to the lights prescribed in paragraph (a) of this Rule, exhibit a high intensity all-round flashing red light.

question: What speed must vessels proceed at in restricted visibility?
truth_answer: A safe speed adapted to the prevailing circumstances and conditions of restricted visibility.

supporting_quotes.quote: Every vessel shall proceed at a safe speed adapted to the prevailing circumstances and conditions of restricted visibility.

question: What engine readiness is required in restricted visibility?
truth_answer: Power-driven vessels shall have engines ready for immediate manoeuvre.

supporting_quotes.quote: A power-driven vessel shall have engines ready for immediate manoeuvre.

question: What course alteration should be avoided for a vessel detected forward of the beam in restricted visibility?
truth_answer: An alteration to port, except for a vessel being overtaken.

supporting_quotes.quote: an alteration of course to port for a vessel forward of the beam, other than for a vessel being overtaken

question: What should be avoided when a vessel is detected abeam in restricted visibility?
truth_answer: An alteration of course towards a vessel abeam or abaft the beam.

supporting_quotes.quote: an alteration of course towards a vessel abeam or abaft the beam.

question: What must a vessel do when hearing a fog signal forward of the beam?
truth_answer: Reduce speed to minimum to keep on course, take all way off if necessary, and navigate with extreme caution.

supporting_quotes.quote: every vessel which hears apparently forward of her beam the fog signal of another vessel shall reduce her speed to the minimum at which she can be kept on her course. She shall if necessary take all her way off and in any event navigate with extreme caution

question: To which vessels does Rule 19 apply?
truth_answer: Vessels not in sight of one another when navigating in or near restricted visibility.

supporting_quotes.quote: This Rule applies to vessels not in sight of one another when navigating in or near an area of restricted visibility.

question: When must shapes be exhibited?
truth_answer: By day.

supporting_quotes.quote: The Rules concerning shapes shall be complied with by day.

question: What arc does a masthead light show?
truth_answer: 225 degrees, from right ahead to 22.5 degrees abaft the beam on either side.

supporting_quotes.quote: Masthead light' means a white light placed over the fore and aft centerline of the vessel showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 225 degrees

question: What arc does a sternlight show?
truth_answer: 135 degrees, 67.5 degrees from right aft on each side.

supporting_quotes.quote: Sternlight' means a white light placed as nearly as practicable at the stern showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 135 degrees and so fixed as to show the light 67.5 degrees from right aft on each side

question: What color are sidelights?
truth_answer: Green on starboard, red on port.

supporting_quotes.quote: Sidelights' means a green light on the starboard side and a red light on the port side

question: What is the visibility range for a sternlight on a vessel 50 metres or more?
truth_answer: 3 miles.

supporting_quotes.quote: In vessels of 50 metres or more in length: a sternlight, 3 miles

question: What is the visibility range for sidelights on vessels under 12 metres?
truth_answer: 1 mile.

supporting_quotes.quote: In vessels of less than 12 metres in length: a sidelight, 1 mile

question: What is the minimum height of the forward masthead light on a vessel 20 metres or more?
truth_answer: Not less than 6 metres, or not less than the breadth if breadth exceeds 6 metres, up to maximum 12 metres.

supporting_quotes.quote: the forward masthead light, or if only one masthead light is carried, then that light, at a height above the hull of not less than 6 meters, and, if the breadth of the vessel exceeds 6 meters, then at a height above the hull not less than such breadth, so however that the light need not be placed at a greater height above the hull than 12 metres

question: What is the minimum vertical separation to ensure the after masthead light is seen over the forward one?
truth_answer: Such that in all normal trim conditions the after light will be seen over the forward light at 1000 metres from the stem.

supporting_quotes.quote: The vertical separation of mastheadlights of power-driven vessels shall be such that in all normal conditions of trim the after light will be seen over and separate from the forward light at a distance of 1,000 meters from the stem when viewed from sea level.

question: What is the minimum height for a masthead light on a vessel 12-20 metres?
truth_answer: Not less than 2.5 metres above the gunwale.

supporting_quotes.quote: The masthead light of a power-driven vessel of 12 metres but less than 20 metres in length shall be placed at a height above the gunwale of not less than 2.5 metres.

question: How high must sidelights be above the hull on power-driven vessels?
truth_answer: Not greater than three quarters of the forward masthead light height, and not so low as to be interfered with by deck lights.

supporting_quotes.quote: The sidelights of a power-driven vessel shall be placed at a height above the hull not greater than three quarters of that of the forward masthead light. They shall not be so low as to be interfered with by deck lights.

question: What is the minimum spacing between vertical lights on vessels 20 metres or more?
truth_answer: Not less than 2 metres apart.

supporting_quotes.quote: on a vessel of 20 metres in length or more such lights shall be spaced not less than 2 metres apart

question: Where must the forward masthead light be located?
truth_answer: Not more than one quarter of the vessel's length from the stem.

supporting_quotes.quote: The forward light shall be placed not more than one quarter of the length of the vessel from the stem.

question: Can sidelights be placed forward of the forward masthead light?
truth_answer: No, on a vessel 20 metres or more, sidelights shall not be placed in front of the forward masthead lights.

supporting_quotes.quote: On a power-driven vessel of 20 m or more in length the sidelights shall not be placed in front of the forward masthead lights.

question: What is the horizontal distance limit for the direction-indicating fishing gear light?
truth_answer: Not less than 2 metres and not more than 6 metres from the two all-round lights.

supporting_quotes.quote: The light indicating the direction of the outlying gear from a vessel engaged in fishing shall be placed at a horizontal distance of not less than 2 metres and not more than 6 metres away from the two all-round red and white lights.

question: What is the minimum diameter for a cone shape?
truth_answer: Not less than 0.6 metre base diameter, with height equal to its diameter.

supporting_quotes.quote: a cone shall have a base diameter of not less than 0.6 metre and a height equal to its diameter

question: What is the minimum diameter for a cylinder shape?
truth_answer: At least 0.6 metre, with height twice its diameter.

supporting_quotes.quote: a cylinder shall have a diameter of at least 0.6 metre and a height of twice its diameter

question: Can vessels under 20 metres use smaller shapes?
truth_answer: Yes, shapes of lesser dimensions commensurate with vessel size may be used, with correspondingly reduced spacing.

supporting_quotes.quote: In a vessel of less than 20 metres in length shapes of lesser dimensions but commensurate with the size of the vessel may be used and the distance apart may be correspondingly reduced.

question: What color must shapes be?
truth_answer: Black.

supporting_quotes.quote: Shapes shall be black and of the following sizes:

question: What is the atmospheric transmissivity value K used for calculating light intensity?
truth_answer: 0.8, corresponding to meteorological visibility of approximately 13 nautical miles.

supporting_quotes.quote: For prescribed lights the value of K shall be 0.8, corresponding to a meteorological visibility of approximately 13 nautical miles.

question: What is the threshold factor T for calculating navigation light intensity?
truth_answer: 210 lux.

supporting_quotes.quote: T is threshold factor 210-7lux

question: Should maximum luminous intensity of navigation lights be limited?
truth_answer: Yes, to avoid undue glare, but not by variable control.

supporting_quotes.quote: The maximum luminous intensity of navigation lights should be limited to avoid undue glare. This shall not be achieved by a variable control of the luminous intensity.

question: Where must practical cutoff occur for sidelights outside prescribed sectors?
truth_answer: Between 1 and 3 degrees outside the prescribed sectors.

supporting_quotes.quote: In the forward direction, sidelights as fitted on the vessel shall show the minimum required intensities. The intensities must decrease to reach practical cut-off between 1 degree and 3 degrees outside the prescribed sectors.

question: Can an all-round light be obscured by masts?
truth_answer: Not within angular sectors of more than 6 degrees, except anchor lights which need not be at impracticable height.

supporting_quotes.quote: All-round lights shall be so located as not to be obscured by masts, topmasts or structures within angular sectors of more than 6 degrees, except anchor lights prescribed in Rule 30

question: What is the minimum vertical angle for electric lights on power vessels?
truth_answer: At least the required minimum intensity from 5 degrees above to 5 degrees below horizontal.

supporting_quotes.quote: at least the required minimum intensity is maintained at all angles from 5 degrees above to 5 degrees below the horizontal

question: What is the extended vertical sector for sailing vessel lights?
truth_answer: At least 50% of minimum intensity from 25 degrees above to 25 degrees below horizontal.

supporting_quotes.quote: at least 50 per cent of the required minimum intensity is maintained from 25 degrees above to 25 degrees below the horizontal.

question: Where should the manoeuvring light be placed?
truth_answer: In the same fore-aft vertical plane as the masthead lights, at least 2 metres vertically above the forward masthead light where practicable.

supporting_quotes.quote: the manoeuvring light described in Rule 34(b) shall be placed in the same fore and aft vertical plane as the masthead light or lights and, where practicable, at a minimum height of 2 metres vertically above the forward masthead light

question: What signals do trawlers show when shooting nets?
truth_answer: Two white lights in a vertical line.

supporting_quotes.quote: when shooting their nets : two white lights in a vertical line

question: What signals do trawlers show when hauling nets?
truth_answer: One white light over one red light in a vertical line.

supporting_quotes.quote: when hauling their nets : one white light over one red light in a vertical line

question: What signals indicate a trawler's net is fast upon an obstruction?
truth_answer: Two red lights in a vertical line.

supporting_quotes.quote: when the net has come fast upon an obstruction : two red lights in a vertical line.

question: What directional light do pair trawlers exhibit?
truth_answer: By night, a searchlight directed forward and toward the other vessel of the pair.

supporting_quotes.quote: by night, a searchlight directed forward and in the direction of the other vessel of the pair

question: What lights may purse seiners exhibit?
truth_answer: Two yellow lights in a vertical line flashing alternately every second.

supporting_quotes.quote: Vessels engaged in fishing with purse seine gear may exhibit two yellow lights in a vertical line. These lights shall flash alternately every second and with equal light and occultation duration.

question: When may purse seiners show alternating yellow lights?
truth_answer: Only when the vessel is hampered by its fishing gear.

supporting_quotes.quote: These lights may be exhibited only when the vessel is hampered by its fishing gear.

question: What is the visibility range for additional fishing vessel signals?
truth_answer: At least 1 mile but at a lesser distance than lights prescribed by COLREG for fishing vessels.

supporting_quotes.quote: The lights shall be visible all round the horizon at a distance of at least 1 mile but at a lesser distance than the lights prescribed by these Rules for fishing vessels.

question: What is the minimum spacing for additional fishing vessel lights?
truth_answer: At least 0.9 metre apart and at a lower level than Rule 26 lights.

supporting_quotes.quote: They shall be at least 0.9 metre apart but at a lower level than lights prescribed in Rule 26(b)(i) and (c)(i).

question: What is the fundamental frequency range for a whistle on vessels under 75 metres?

supporting_quotes.quote: 250 - 700 Hz, for a vessel less than 75 metres in length.

question: What is the audibility range for a whistle on a vessel 75-200 metres?
truth_answer: 1.5 nautical miles.

supporting_quotes.quote: 75 but less than 200 138 1.5

question: What is the maximum sound pressure reduction for a directional whistle off-axis?
truth_answer: Not more than 4 dB below prescribed level within 45 degrees of axis; not more than 10 dB in other horizontal directions.

supporting_quotes.quote: The sound pressure level of a directional whistle shall be not more than 4 dB below the prescribed sound pressure level on the axis at any direction in the horizontal plane within 45 degrees of the axis. The sound pressure level at any other direction in the horizontal plane shall be not more than 10 dB below the prescribed sound pressure level on the axis

question: Where should a directional whistle point?
truth_answer: With maximum intensity directed straight ahead.

supporting_quotes.quote: When a directional whistle is to be used as the only whistle on a vessel, it shall be installed with its maximum intensity directed straight ahead.

question: What is the maximum sound pressure level at listening posts from the vessel's own whistle?
truth_answer: Shall not exceed 110 dB(A) and so far as practicable should not exceed 100 dB(A).

supporting_quotes.quote: The sound pressure level of the vessel's own signal at listening posts shall not exceed 110 dB (A) and so far as practicable should not exceed 100 dB (A).

question: What is the minimum frequency difference between whistles in a combined system?
truth_answer: At least 10 Hz.

supporting_quotes.quote: The frequency of any one whistle shall differ from those of the others by at least 10 Hz

question: Can whistles more than 100 metres apart sound simultaneously?
truth_answer: No, they shall be arranged so they are not sounded simultaneously.

supporting_quotes.quote: If whistles are fitted at a distance apart of more than 100 m, it shall be so arranged that they are not sounded simultaneously.

question: What material must bells and gongs be made of?
truth_answer: Corrosion-resistant material designed to give a clear tone.

supporting_quotes.quote: Bells and gongs shall be made of corrosion-resistant material and designed to give a clear tone.

question: What type of bell striker is recommended?
truth_answer: A power-driven bell striker to ensure constant force, though manual operation must be possible.

supporting_quotes.quote: Where practicable, a power-driven bell striker is recommended to ensure constant force but manual operation shall be possible.

question: What signal does a towed vessel make in restricted visibility?
truth_answer: Four blasts in succession (one prolonged followed by three short) at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel towed or if more than one vessel is towed the last vessel of the tow, if manned, shall at intervals of not more than 2 minutes sound four blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by three short blasts.

question: Can a vessel at anchor sound a whistle signal in restricted visibility?
truth_answer: Yes, in addition to the bell, she may sound three blasts (one short, one prolonged, one short) to warn approaching vessels.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel at anchor may in addition sound three blasts in succession, namely one short, one prolonged and one short blast, to give warning of her position and of the possibility of collision to an approaching vessel.

question: What bell signal does a vessel aground make?
truth_answer: Three separate strokes on the bell immediately before and after the rapid ringing, plus the anchor bell signal.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel aground shall give the bell signal and if required the gone signal prescribed in paragraph (g) and shall, in addition, give three separate and distinct strokes on the bell immediately before and after the rapid ringing

question: Are vessels 12-20 metres required to give bell signals?
truth_answer: No, but if they don't, they shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel of 12 metres or more but less than 20 metres in length shall not be obliged to give the bell signals prescribed in paragraphs (g) and (h) of this Rule. However, if she does not, she shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.

question: Must vessels under 12 metres make fog signals?
truth_answer: Not obliged to give prescribed signals, but if not, shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel of less than 12 metres in length shall not be obliged to give the above-mentioned signals but, if she does not, shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.

question: Can lights be used to attract attention of another vessel?
truth_answer: Yes, but such lights cannot be mistaken for navigation aids or authorized signals.

supporting_quotes.quote: If necessary to attract the attention of another vessel any vessel may make light or sound signals that cannot be mistaken for any signal authorized elsewhere in these Rules

question: Should strobe lights be used to attract attention?
truth_answer: No, high intensity intermittent or revolving lights such as strobe lights shall be avoided.

supporting_quotes.quote: For the purpose of this Rule the use of high intensity intermittent or revolving lights, such as strove lights, shall be avoided.

question: Can a searchlight beam be directed at another vessel?
truth_answer: Yes, to indicate danger, but in such a way as not to embarrass any vessel.

supporting_quotes.quote: any vessel may make light or sound signals that cannot be mistaken for any signal authorized elsewhere in these Rules, or may direct the beam of her searchlight in the direction of the danger, in such a way as not to embarrass any vessel.

question: What does a continuous sounding of fog apparatus indicate?
truth_answer: Distress and need of assistance.

supporting_quotes.quote: a continuous sounding with any fog-signalling apparatus

question: What pyrotechnic signals indicate distress?
truth_answer: Rockets or shells throwing red stars fired one at a time at short intervals, or a rocket parachute flare showing red light.

supporting_quotes.quote: rockets or shells, throwing red stars fired one at a time at short intervals

question: What is the International Code Signal for distress?
truth_answer: N.C.

supporting_quotes.quote: the International Code Signal of distress indicated by N.C.

question: What visible flame indicates distress?
truth_answer: Flames on the vessel such as from a burning tar barrel or oil barrel.

supporting_quotes.quote: flames on the vessel (as from a burning tar barrel, oil barrel, etc.)

question: What frequency does DSC distress alert use on VHF?
truth_answer: VHF channel 70.

supporting_quotes.quote: VHF channel 70

question: Can emergency position-indicating radio beacons signal distress?
truth_answer: Yes, signals transmitted by emergency position-indicating radio beacons indicate distress.

supporting_quotes.quote: signals transmitted by emergency position-indicating radio beacons

question: Can satellite systems transmit distress alerts?
truth_answer: Yes, ship-to-shore distress alerts transmitted by Inmarsat or other mobile satellite service provider ship earth stations.

supporting_quotes.quote: a ship-to-shore distress alert transmitted by the ship's Inmarsat or other mobile satellite service provider ship earth station

question: What dye marker color indicates distress?
truth_answer: The use of a dye marker (color not specified in rules, but context suggests visibility).

supporting_quotes.quote: a dye marker.

question: What aerial identification signal indicates distress?
truth_answer: A piece of orange-coloured canvas with a black square and circle or other appropriate symbol.

supporting_quotes.quote: a piece of orange-coloured canvas with either a black square and circle or other appropriate symbol (for identification from the air)

question: What explosive signal interval indicates distress?
truth_answer: A gun or other explosive signal fired at intervals of about a minute.

supporting_quotes.quote: a gun or other explosive signals fired at intervals of about a minute

question: Does Rule 2 exonerate vessels from consequences of neglecting the Rules?
truth_answer: No, nothing in the Rules exonerates any vessel or crew from consequences of neglect.

supporting_quotes.quote: Nothing in these Rules shall exonerate any vessel, or the owner, master or crew thereof, from the consequences of any neglect to comply with these Rules

question: Can vessel limitations justify departure from the Rules?
truth_answer: Yes, special circumstances including vessel limitations may make departure necessary to avoid immediate danger.

supporting_quotes.quote: In construing and complying with these Rules due regard shall be had to all dangers of navigation and collision and to any special circumstances, including the limitations of the vessels involved, which may make a departure from these Rules necessary to avoid immediate danger.

question: Are trolling lines considered fishing apparatus that restricts manoeuvrability?
truth_answer: No, trolling lines do not restrict manoeuvrability.

supporting_quotes.quote: The term 'vessel engaged in fishing' means any vessel fishing with nets, lines, trawls or other fishing apparatus which restrict manoeuvrability, but does not include a vessel fishing with trolling lines

question: What examples of underwater operations restrict vessel manoeuvrability?
truth_answer: Dredging, surveying or underwater operations.

supporting_quotes.quote: a vessel engaged in dredging, surveying or underwater operations

question: Does transferring cargo underway restrict manoeuvrability?
truth_answer: Yes, replenishment or transferring persons, provisions or cargo while underway restricts ability to manoeuvre.

supporting_quotes.quote: a vessel engaged in replenishment or transferring persons, provisions or cargo while underway

question: Does aircraft launch/recovery restrict vessel manoeuvrability?
truth_answer: Yes, a vessel engaged in launching or recovery of aircraft is restricted in ability to manoeuvre.

supporting_quotes.quote: a vessel engaged in the launching or recovery of aircraft

question: Does mine clearance restrict vessel manoeuvrability?
truth_answer: Yes, a vessel engaged in mineclearance operations is restricted in ability to manoeuvre.

supporting_quotes.quote: a vessel engaged in mineclearance operations

question: Can towing operations restrict manoeuvrability?
truth_answer: Yes, when such operations severely restrict the towing vessel and her tow in their ability to deviate from course.

supporting_quotes.quote: a vessel engaged in a towing operation such as severely restricts the towing vessel and her tow in their ability to deviate from their course.

question: What defines a vessel constrained by draught?
truth_answer: A power-driven vessel severely restricted in ability to deviate from course due to draught relative to available depth and width of water.

supporting_quotes.quote: The term 'vessel constrained by her draught' means a power-driven vessel which because of her draught in relation to the available depth and width of navigable water, is severely restricted in her ability to deviate from the course she is following.

question: What is a WIG craft's main operational mode?
truth_answer: Flies in close proximity to the surface by utilizing surface-effect action.

supporting_quotes.quote: The term 'Wing-In-Ground (WIG) craft' means a multimodal craft which, in its main operational mode, flies in close proximity to the surface by utilizing surface-effect action.

question: Can special rules for warships differ from COLREG?
truth_answer: Yes, governments may make special rules for additional lights, shapes or signals for warships and vessels in convoy.

supporting_quotes.quote: Nothing in these Rules shall interfere with the operation of any special rules made by the Government of any State with respect to additional station or signal lights, shapes or whistle signals for ships of war and vessels proceeding under convoy

question: Must special warship lights avoid confusion with COLREG lights?
truth_answer: Yes, additional lights, shapes or signals shall be such that they cannot be mistaken for lights authorized elsewhere under COLREG.

supporting_quotes.quote: These additional station or signal lights, shapes or whistle signals shall, so far as possible, be such that they cannot be mistaken for any light, shapes or signal authorized elsewhere under these Rules.

question: Who adopts traffic separation schemes?
truth_answer: The Organization (IMO).

supporting_quotes.quote: Traffic separation schemes may be adopted by the Organization for the purpose of these Rules.

question: Can vessels of special construction be exempt from full compliance?
truth_answer: Yes, if unable to fully comply with light, shape or sound requirements, they shall comply as closely as possible as determined by their government.

supporting_quotes.quote: Whenever the Government concerned shall have determined that a vessel of special construction or purpose cannot comply fully with the provisions of any of these Rules with respect to the number, position, range or arc of visibility of lights or shapes, as well as to the disposition and characteristics of sound-signalling appliances, such vessel shall comply with such other provisions

question: Must vessels comply with COLREG in harbor special rules areas?
truth_answer: Special harbor rules may apply, but they shall conform as closely as possible to COLREG.

supporting_quotes.quote: Nothing in these Rules shall interfere with the operation of special rules made by an appropriate authority for roadsteads, harbours, rivers, lakes or inland waterways connected with the high seas and navigable by seagoing vessels. Such special rules shall conform as closely as possible to these Rules.

question: What precautions does ordinary seamanship require beyond the Rules?
truth_answer: Any precaution required by ordinary practice of seamen or special circumstances of the case.

supporting_quotes.quote: Nothing in these Rules shall exonerate any vessel, or the owner, master or crew thereof, from the consequences of any neglect to comply with these Rules or of the neglect of any precaution which may be required by the ordinary practice of seamen, or by the special circumstances of the case.

question: When can lights be exhibited outside sunset-to-sunrise hours?
truth_answer: In restricted visibility from sunrise to sunset, and may be exhibited when deemed necessary in other circumstances.

supporting_quotes.quote: The lights prescribed by these Rules shall, if carried, also be exhibited from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility and may be exhibited in all other circumstances when it is deemed necessary.

question: Must lights and shapes comply with Annex I specifications?
truth_answer: Yes, lights and shapes specified in the Rules shall comply with provisions of Annex I.

supporting_quotes.quote: The lights and shapes specified in these Rules shall comply with the provisions of Annex I to these Regulations.

question: Should other lights impair visibility of navigation lights?
truth_answer: No, no other lights shall be exhibited that can be mistaken for prescribed lights or impair their visibility or distinctive character.

supporting_quotes.quote: during such times no other lights shall be exhibited, except such lights as cannot be mistaken for the lights specified in these Rules or do not impair their visibility or distinctive character, or interfere with the keeping of a proper look-out.

question: Can sidelights be combined in one lantern on vessels under 20 metres?
truth_answer: Yes, on vessels less than 20 metres the sidelights may be combined in one lantern on the fore-aft centreline.

supporting_quotes.quote: In a vessel of less than 20 meters in length the sidelights may be combined in one lantern carried on the fore and aft centreline of the vessel.

question: What arc do sidelights show?
truth_answer: 112.5 degrees from right ahead to 22.5 degrees abaft the beam on each respective side.

supporting_quotes.quote: each showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 112.5 degrees and so fixed as to show the light from right ahead to 22.5 degrees abaft the beam on its respective side.

question: Where is the masthead light placed on the vessel?
truth_answer: Over the fore and aft centerline of the vessel.

supporting_quotes.quote: Masthead light' means a white light placed over the fore and aft centerline of the vessel

question: Can a vessel under 7 metres substitute a torch for navigation lights?
truth_answer: Yes, a sailing vessel under 7 metres shall have ready an electric torch or lighted lantern showing white light if not exhibiting prescribed lights.

supporting_quotes.quote: A sailing vessel of less than 7 metres in length shall, if practicable, exhibit the lights prescribed in paragraph (a) or (b) of this Rule, but if she does not, she shall have ready at hand an electric torch or lighted lantern showing a white light

question: What optional masthead lights may a sailing vessel exhibit?
truth_answer: Two all-round lights in vertical line at or near masthead top, upper red and lower green.

supporting_quotes.quote: A sailing vessel underway may, in addition to the lights prescribed in paragraph (a) of this Rule, exhibit at or near the top of the mast two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower green

question: Can rowing boats show sailing vessel lights?
truth_answer: Yes, a vessel under oars may exhibit lights for sailing vessels, or have ready an electric torch or lantern showing white light.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel under oars may exhibit the lights prescribed in this Rule for sailing vessels, but if she does not, she shall have ready at hand an electric torch or lighted lantern showing a white light

question: What shape must a motor-sailing vessel display?
truth_answer: A conical shape apex downwards forward where it can best be seen.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel proceeding under sail when also being propelled by machinery shall exhibit forward where it can best be seen a conical shape, apex down wards.

question: Must fishing vessels display only the lights prescribed in Rule 26?
truth_answer: Yes, a vessel engaged in fishing shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel engaged in fishing, whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in this Rule.

question: What defines trawling in COLREG?
truth_answer: Dragging through the water of a dredge net or other apparatus used as a fishing appliance.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel when engaged in trawling, by which is meant the dragging through the water of a dredge net or other apparatus used as a fishing appliance

question: What color lights identify a trawler?
truth_answer: Two all-round lights in vertical line, upper green and lower white.

supporting_quotes.quote: two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being green and the lower white

question: What color lights identify a vessel fishing (not trawling)?
truth_answer: Two all-round lights in vertical line, upper red and lower white.

supporting_quotes.quote: two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower white

question: What additional lights do fishing vessels making way exhibit?
truth_answer: Sidelights and a sternlight.

supporting_quotes.quote: when making way through the water, in addition to the lights prescribed in this paragraph, sidelights and a sternlight.

question: Must trawlers 50 metres or more display an aft masthead light?
truth_answer: Not obliged but may do so - a masthead light abaft and higher than the all-round green light.

supporting_quotes.quote: a masthead light abaft of and higher than the all-round green light; a vessel of less than 50 metres in length shall not be obliged to exhibit such a light but may do so

question: Do Annex II signals apply to fishing vessels?
truth_answer: Yes, additional signals for vessels fishing in close proximity to other fishing vessels apply.

supporting_quotes.quote: The additional signals described in Annex II to these Regulations apply to a vessel engaged in fishing in close proximity to other vessels engaged in fishing.

question: Must a vessel show fishing lights when not fishing?
truth_answer: No, when not engaged in fishing she shall exhibit only lights for a vessel of her length.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel when not engaged in fishing shall not exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed in this Rule, but only those prescribed for a vessel of her length.

question: What lights identify a vessel not under command?
truth_answer: Two all-round red lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen.

supporting_quotes.quote: two all-round red lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen

question: What shapes identify a vessel not under command by day?
truth_answer: Two balls or similar shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen.

supporting_quotes.quote: two balls or similar shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen

question: What lights identify a vessel restricted in ability to manoeuvre?
truth_answer: Three all-round lights in vertical line (highest and lowest red, middle white) where they can best be seen.

supporting_quotes.quote: three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white

question: What shapes identify a vessel restricted in ability to manoeuvre by day?
truth_answer: Three shapes in vertical line (highest and lowest balls, middle diamond) where they can best be seen.

supporting_quotes.quote: three shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these shapes shall be balls and the middle one a diamond

question: What additional lights does RAM vessel making way display?
truth_answer: Masthead light(s), sidelights and sternlight in addition to the three vertical lights.

supporting_quotes.quote: when making way through the water, a masthead light or lights, sidelights and a sternlight in addition to the lights prescribed in subparagraph (i)

question: What lights does a towing vessel with severely restricted manoeuvrability show?
truth_answer: The lights for towing in Rule 24(a) plus the RAM lights and shapes in Rule 27(b)(i) and (ii).

supporting_quotes.quote: A power-driven vessel engaged in a towing operation such as severely restricts the towing vessel and her tow in their ability to deviate from their course shall, in addition to the lights or shapes prescribed in Rule 24(a), exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed in sub-paragraphs (b)(i) and (ii) of this Rule.

question: Which side of a dredger shows two red lights or balls?
truth_answer: The obstructed side.

supporting_quotes.quote: two all-round red lights or two balls in a vertical line to indicate the side on which the obstruction exists

question: Which side of a dredger shows two green lights or diamonds?
truth_answer: The side on which another vessel may pass.

supporting_quotes.quote: two all-round green lights or two diamonds in a vertical line to indicate the side on which another vessel may pass

question: What lights identify a vessel engaged in mineclearance?
truth_answer: Lights for power-driven vessel or anchor as appropriate, plus three all-round green lights or three balls.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel engaged in mineclearance operations shall in addition to the lights prescribed for a power-driven vessel in Rule 23 or to the lights or shape prescribed for a vessel at anchor in Rule 30 as appropriate, exhibit three all-round green lights or three balls.

question: Where are the three green lights/balls positioned on a mineclearance vessel?
truth_answer: One near foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard.

supporting_quotes.quote: One of these lights or shapes shall be exhibited near the foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard.

question: What safe distance do mineclearance lights indicate?
truth_answer: It is dangerous for another vessel to approach within 1000 metres.

supporting_quotes.quote: These lights or shapes indicate that it is dangerous for another vessel to approach within 1000 metres of the mineclearance vessel.

question: What lights can small diving vessels show instead of full RAM lights?
truth_answer: Three all-round lights in vertical line (highest and lowest red, middle white) plus a rigid replica of Code flag A not less than 1 metre high.

supporting_quotes.quote: three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white; a rigid replica of the International Code flag 'A' not less than 1 metre in height.

question: Are NUC and RAM signals also distress signals?
truth_answer: No, signals in Rule 27 are not signals of vessels in distress.

supporting_quotes.quote: The signals prescribed in this Rule are not signals of vessels in distress and requiring assistance. Such signals are contained in Annex IV to these Regulations

question: Can a vessel under 50 metres display only one anchor light?
truth_answer: Yes, an all-round white light where it can best be seen instead of the two prescribed lights.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel of less than 50 metres in length may exhibit an all-round white light where it can best be seen instead of the lights prescribed in paragraph (a) of this Rule.

question: Must large vessels illuminate their decks when at anchor?
truth_answer: A vessel 100 metres or more shall illuminate decks; other vessels may do so.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel at anchor may, and a vessel of 100 metres and more in length shall, also use the available working or equivalent lights to illuminate her decks.

question: Can vessels under 12 metres aground omit aground signals?
truth_answer: Yes, vessels less than 12 metres when aground are not required to exhibit the lights or shapes for vessels aground.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel of less than 12 metres in length, when aground, shall not be required to exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed in sub-paragraphs (d)(i) and (ii) of this Rule.

question: What lights identify a pilot vessel underway?
truth_answer: Two all-round lights in vertical line at/near masthead (upper white, lower red), plus sidelights and sternlight.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel engaged on pilotage duty shall exhibit: at or near the masthead, two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being white and the lower red; when underway, in addition, sidelight and a sternlight

question: What lights does a pilot vessel not on duty display?
truth_answer: The lights or shapes prescribed for a similar vessel of her length.

supporting_quotes.quote: A pilot vessel when not engaged on pilotage duty shall exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed for a similar vessel of her length.

question: Where can seaplanes and WIG craft deviate from light requirements?
truth_answer: Where impracticable to exhibit lights and shapes as prescribed, they shall exhibit lights and shapes as closely similar as possible.

supporting_quotes.quote: Where it is impracticable for a seaplane or a WIG craft to exhibit lights and shapes of the characteristics or in the positions prescribed in the Rules of this Part she shall exhibit lights and shapes as closely similar in characteristics and position as is possible.

question: What defines a whistle in COLREG?
truth_answer: Any sound signalling appliance capable of producing prescribed blasts and complying with Annex III specifications.

supporting_quotes.quote: The word 'whistle' means any sound signalling appliance capable of producing the prescribed blasts and which complies with the specifications in Annex III to these Regulations.

question: Can vessels under 12 metres use other means for sound signals?
truth_answer: Yes, if not carrying prescribed appliances, they shall have some other means of making an efficient sound signal.

supporting_quotes.quote: A vessel of less than 12 metres in length shall not be obliged to carry the sound signalling appliances prescribed in paragraph (a) of this Rule but if she does not, she shall be provided with some other means of making an efficient sound signal.

question: Should light signals be used instead of whistle signals?
truth_answer: No, whistle signals may be supplemented by light signals, not replaced.

supporting_quotes.quote: Any vessel may supplement the whistle signals prescribed in paragraph (a) of this Rule by light signals, repeated as appropriate, whilst the manoeuvre is being carried out

question: What does one flash of a manoeuvring light mean?
truth_answer: I am altering my course to starboard.

supporting_quotes.quote: one flash to mean 'I am altering my course to starboard '

question: What does two flashes of a manoeuvring light mean?
truth_answer: I am altering my course to port.

supporting_quotes.quote: two flashes to mean 'I am altering my course to port '

question: What does three flashes of a manoeuvring light mean?
truth_answer: I am operating astern propulsion.

supporting_quotes.quote: three flashes to mean 'I am operating astern propulsion'

question: What is the minimum range for a manoeuvring light?
truth_answer: Visible at minimum 5 miles if fitted.

supporting_quotes.quote: the light used for this signals shall, if fitted, be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles

question: When must an approaching vessel answer a bend signal?
truth_answer: Any approaching vessel within hearing around the bend shall answer with a prolonged blast.

supporting_quotes.quote: Such signal shall be answered with a prolonged blast by any approaching vessel that may be within hearing around the bend or behind the intervening obstruction.

question: If multiple whistles are fitted, how many should sound manoeuvring signals?
truth_answer: One whistle only if whistles are more than 100 metres apart.

supporting_quotes.quote: If whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 metres, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

question: What fog signal does a composite unit make?
truth_answer: The signals for a power-driven vessel in Rule 35(a) or (b).

supporting_quotes.quote: When a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit they shall be regarded as a power-driven vessel and shall give the signals prescribed in paragraphs (a) or (b) of this Rule.

question: When should a towed vessel make its fog signal?
truth_answer: Immediately after the signal made by the towing vessel, when practicable.

supporting_quotes.quote: When practicable, this signal shall be made immediately after the signal made by the towing vessel.

question: What defines 'height above the hull' in Annex I?
truth_answer: Height above the uppermost continuous deck, measured from the position vertically beneath the light's location.

supporting_quotes.quote: The term 'height above the hull' means height above the uppermost continuous deck. This height shall be measured from the position vertically beneath the location of the light.

question: What is the minimum height for the lowest vertical light except towing lights?
truth_answer: Not less than 4 metres above the hull on vessels 20 metres or more; 2 metres above gunwale on vessels under 20 metres.

supporting_quotes.quote: the lowest of these lights shall, except where a towing light is required, be placed at a height of not less than 4 m above the hull

question: How are three vertical lights spaced?
truth_answer: Equally spaced.

supporting_quotes.quote: when three lights are carried they shall be equally spaced.

question: Where must the forward anchor light be on vessels 50 metres or more?
truth_answer: Not less than 6 metres above the hull and not less than 4.5 metres above the after anchor light.

supporting_quotes.quote: The forward anchor light prescribed in Rule 30(a)(i), when two are carried, shall not be less than 4.5 metres above the after one. On a vessel of 50 metres or more in length this forward anchor light shall be placed at a height of not less than 6 metres above the hull.

question: Where must a single masthead light be exhibited?
truth_answer: Forward of amidships, except vessels under 20 metres may exhibit it as far forward as practicable.

supporting_quotes.quote: When only one masthead light is prescribed for a power driven vessel, this light shall be exhibited forward of amidships; except that a vessel of less than 20 m in length need not exhibit this light forward of amidships but shall exhibit it as far forward as is practicable.

question: What is the maximum distance sidelights may be placed inboard from the vessel's side?
truth_answer: Not more than 10% of breadth inboard from the side, up to maximum 1 metre.

supporting_quotes.quote: The term 'near the side' is interpreted as being a distance of not more than 10% of the breadth of the vessel inboard from the side, up to a maximum of 1 metre.

question: Can small vessels use screens for sidelights?
truth_answer: Yes, on vessels under 20 metres, sidelights shall be fitted with inboard screens if necessary to meet Section 9 requirements.

supporting_quotes.quote: On vessels of less than 20metres in length the sidelights, if necessary to meet the requirements of Section 9 of this Annex, shall be fitted with inboard matt black screens.

question: When are external sidelight screens not needed?
truth_answer: With a combined lantern using a single vertical filament and a very narrow division between green and red sections.

supporting_quotes.quote: With a combined lantern, using a single vertical filament and a very narrow division between the green and red sections, external screens need not be fitted.

question: Must sidelights on vessels 20 metres or more have screens?
truth_answer: Yes, fitted with inboard screens painted matt black meeting Section 9 requirements.

supporting_quotes.quote: The sidelights of vessels of 20 metres or more in length shall be fitted with inboard screens painted matt black, and meeting the requirements of Section 9 of this Annex.

question: What is the minimum horizontal distance for RAM/NUC lights placed between masthead lights?
truth_answer: Not less than 2 metres from the fore-aft centreline in the athwartship direction.

supporting_quotes.quote: When the lights prescribed in Rule 27(b)(i) or Rule 28 are placed vertically between the forward masthead light(s) and the after masthead light(s) these all-round lights shall be placed at a horizontal distance of not less than 2 m from the fore and after centreline of the vessel in the athwartship direction.

question: How far must the fishing gear direction light be from the red/white lights?
truth_answer: Not less than 2 metres and not more than 6 metres horizontally.

supporting_quotes.quote: The light indicating the direction of the outlying gear from a vessel engaged in fishing shall be placed at a horizontal distance of not less than 2 metres and not more than 6 metres away from the two all-round red and white lights.

question: What is the height limitation for the fishing gear direction light?
truth_answer: Not higher than the all-round white light in Rule 26(c)(i) and not lower than the sidelights.

supporting_quotes.quote: This light shall be placed not higher than the all-round white light prescribed in Rule 26(c)(i) and not lower than the sidelights.

question: What is the minimum horizontal distance for dredger obstruction lights?
truth_answer: At least 2 metres from the RAM lights.

supporting_quotes.quote: The lights and shapes on a vessel engaged in dredging or underwater operations to indicate the obstructed side and/or the side on which it is safe to pass shall be placed at the maximum practical horizontal distance, but in no case less than 2 metres, from the lights or shapes prescribed in Rule 27(b)(i) and (ii).

question: What is the height limit for dredger obstruction lights relative to RAM lights?
truth_answer: The upper obstruction light shall not be at greater height than the lower of the three RAM lights.

supporting_quotes.quote: In no case shall the upper of these lights or shapes be at a greater height than the lower of the three lights or shapes prescribed in Rule 27(b)(i) and (ii).

question: How much may intensity decrease 5 degrees within prescribed sectors?
truth_answer: May decrease by 50% from 5 degrees within prescribed limits to the sector limits.

supporting_quotes.quote: From 5 degrees within the prescribed sectors the intensity may decrease by 50 percent up to the prescribed limits

question: Where must practical cutoff occur for masthead and sternlights?
truth_answer: Intensity shall decrease steadily to reach practical cutoff at not more than 5 degrees outside prescribed sectors.

supporting_quotes.quote: it shall decrease steadily to reach practical cut-off at not more than 5 degrees outside the prescribed sectors.

question: When must two all-round lights be used instead of one?
truth_answer: When impracticable to show one all-round light unobscured, two suitably positioned or screened lights shall appear as one at 1 mile.

supporting_quotes.quote: If it is impracticable to comply with paragraph (b)(i) of this section by exhibiting only one all-round light, two all-round lights shall be used suitably positioned or screened so that they appear, as far as practicable, as one light at a distance of one mile.

question: What percentage of minimum intensity must be maintained 7.5 degrees from horizontal?
truth_answer: At least 60% for power vessels; 50% for sailing vessels at 25 degrees.

supporting_quotes.quote: at least 60 per cent of the required minimum intensity is maintained from 7.5 degrees above to 7.5 degrees below the horizontal.

question: Must non-electric lights meet the same intensity requirements?
truth_answer: Non-electric lights shall so far as practicable comply with minimum intensities specified.

supporting_quotes.quote: Non-electric lights shall so far as practicable comply with the minimum intensities, as specified in the Table given in Section 8 of this Annex.

question: Where should the manoeuvring light be if only one masthead light is carried?
truth_answer: Where it can best be seen, not less than 2 metres vertically apart from the masthead light.

supporting_quotes.quote: On a vessel where only one masthead light is carried the manoeuvring light, if fitted, shall be carried where it can best be seen, not less than 2 metres vertically apart from the masthead light.

question: What is the minimum masthead light height formula for high-speed craft 50 metres or more?
truth_answer: The vertical separation formula ensures safe geometry: y = (a + 17) + (C/2) where y is separation in metres.

supporting_quotes.quote: y is the height of the mainmast light above the fore mast light in metres; a is the height of the foremast light above the water surface in service condition in metres;  is the trim in service condition in degrees; C is the horizontal separation of masthead lights in metres.
